trial_identification.studytitle: Retinal Artery Study in participants with obstructive sleep apnoea treated with continuous positive airway pressure
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A pilot, randomised controlled trial of retinal artery flicker induced vasodilatation to detect change in endothelial function in participants with obstructive sleep apnoea treated with continuous postitive airway pressure for 6 weeks.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Diseases of the vasculature and circulation including the lymphatic system

interventions.interventions: 6 weeks Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) individually titrated and fitted for use during sleep.

primaryOutcome.outcome: The Dynamic Vessel Analyzer (IMEDOS, Germany) is used to measure retinal vascular endothelial function. Changes in ocular haemodynamic parameters expressed as the percentage change over baseline values in response to flicker light stimulation.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: After 6 weeks of treatment with CPAP or no CPAP

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Moderate to severe Obstructive Sleep Apnoea(OSA) - Apnoea Hypopnoea Index greater than or equal to 30, with associated hypoxaemia Oxygen saturation(Sa O2) <90% for a minimumm of 6% of total sleep time. Actual coronary artery disease or two or more of the following cardiovascular risk factors hypertension, dyslipidaemia, diabetes, smoking, positive family history.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Commercial driver or patients listed for urgent CPAP implementation. Glaucoma

trial_design.sequence: Simple randomisation by using a randomization table created by a computer software

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: Austin Health Department of Cardiology and Institute for Breathing and Sleep

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Evidence has accumulated that changes to the tiny blood vessels at the back of the eye (retinal arteries) are linked to heart disease. It is possible to use a simple eye examination to view these tiny retinal blood vessels and get an idea about their condition. This kind of examination is simple to perform and is not invasive. Because there are similarities to blood vessels throughout the body, an eye examination could be used to provide important information about blood vessel condition in general and whether certain treatments can result in improved blood vessel function. This study will examine the retinal arteries of a group of patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnoea and risk factors for or actual heart disease. It will also look for evidence that the function of the retinal arteries improves with Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) treatment
